query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Chi poria mai pur con parole sciolte 2 dicer del sangue e de le piaghe a pieno 3 ch’i’ ora vidi, per narrar più volte?
4 Ogne lingua per certo verria meno 5 per lo nostro sermone e per la mente 6 c’hanno a tanto comprender poco seno.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Who could ever with unfettered words 2 fully tell of the blood and the wounds 3 that I saw then, to recount them many times?
4 Every tongue would surely fail 5 because of our speech and because of our minds, 6 which have too little capacity to grasp so much.
**Old English:**
1 Hwa mæg ðonne mid unbundenre spræce 2 secgan ðæs wæteres and ðara wunda ful 3 ðe ic ða geseah, ðæt ic secgan mæge?
4 Æghwylc tunge bið gebunden 5 ðurh ure spræce and ðurh ure geðoht, 6 ðe habbað to lyt ðæs andgites.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 S’el s’aunasse ancor tutta la gente 8 che già, in su la fortunata terra 9 di Puglia, fu del suo sangue dolente
10 per li Troiani e per la lunga guerra 11 che de l’anella fé sì alte spoglie, 12 come Livïo scrive, che non erra,
13 con quella che sentio di colpi doglie 14 per contastare a Ruberto Guiscardo; 15 e l’altra il cui ossame ancor s’accoglie
16 a Ceperan, là dove fu bugiardo 17 ciascun Pugliese, e là da Tagliacozzo, 18 dove sanz’ arme vinse il vecchio Alardo;
19 e qual forato suo membro e qual mozzo 20 mostrasse, d’aequar sarebbe nulla 21 il modo de la nona bolgia sozzo.
query.result:
**English:**
7 If all the people were to gather again 8 who once, in the fortunate land 9 of Apulia, grieved for their blood,
10 shed for the Trojans and for the long war 11 that made such great spoils of rings, 12 as Livy writes, who does not err,
13 together with her who felt the pangs of blows 14 for opposing Robert Guiscard; 15 and the other whose bones are still gathered
16 at Ceperano, where every Apulian 17 was a liar, and there at Tagliacozzo, 18 where the old Alardo conquered without arms;
19 and if each one were to show his mangled or severed limb, 20 it would be nothing compared to 21 the filth of the ninth bolgia.
**Old English:**
7 Gif eal ðæt folc eft gesamnod wære 8 ðe ær on ðære gelæran eorðan 9 Apuleȝe, wæs for ðam blode geomormod,
10 ðurh ða Troianisce and ða longan gewinn, 11 ðe ðara beaȝa swylce heage reaflac, 12 swa Livius writ, se ðe lyge ne conn,
13 mid ðære ðe ðara wunda wæg dolga 14 wið ðone Rodbeard Guiscard to feohtanne; 15 and oðer ðære ðara ban git gyt licgað
16 æt Ceparanan, ðær ælc Apuleȝisc 17 leas wes, and ðær æt Taliacozze, 18 ðær se ealda Alard sigores geweold;
19 and gif ælc his towundenne lim and towearp 20 æteowde, nære nawiht ðæs gelic 21 ðæs nigedan hellscipes fulnysse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Già veggia, per mezzul perdere o lulla, 23 com’ io vidi un, così non si pertugia, 24 rotto dal mento infin dove si trulla.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Already I can see, through losing half of it, 23 how I saw one, so is not pierced through, 24 split from the chin down to where one breaks wind.
**Old English:**
22 Nu ic mæg geseon, ðurh ðæs middes forlies, 23 hu ic geseah ðone, swa ne bið ðurhþroten, 24 brocen fram ðære cinne oð ðæt hit cyrð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Tra le gambe pendevan le minugia; 26 la corata pareva e ’l tristo sacco 27 che merda fa di quel che si trangugia.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Between his legs his entrails hung down; 26 his stomach and the wretched sack 27 that turns to dung whatever he swallows were visible.
**Old English:**
25 Betwux his þeos ða earmunga hangodon; 26 ða wambe he geseah and ðone wælan sacc 27 ðe ðone mete forðylmð ðe he ðær toslupe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Mentre che tutto in lui veder m’attacco, 29 guardommi e con le man s’aperse il petto, 30 dicendo: «Or vedi com’ io mi dilacco!
31 vedi come storpiato è Mäometto! 32 Dinanzi a me sen va piangendo Alì, 33 fesso nel volto dal mento al ciuffetto.
query.result:
**English:**
28 While I cling to see everything in him, 29 he looks at me and with his hands tears open his chest, 30 saying: "Now see how I am torn apart!
31 See how Mohammed is mutilated! 32 Ali goes weeping before me, 33 his face split from chin to forelock.
**Old English:**
28 Þa hwile þe ic ealne hine geseon wolde, 29 he locode on me and his breost mid handum ontýnde, 30 and cwæð: "Nu geseh ðu hu ic tobrocen eom!
31 Geseoh hu lama Mahmet is! 32 Ær me Ali wepende gæð, 33 on andwlítan tosliten fram cinne oð brune."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E tutti li altri che tu vedi qui, 35 seminator di scandalo e di scisma 36 fuor vivi, e però son fessi così.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Un diavolo è qua dietro che n’accisma 38 sì crudelmente, al taglio de la spada 39 rimettendo ciascun di questa risma,
40 quand’ avem volta la dolente strada; 41 però che le ferite son richiuse 42 prima ch’altri dinanzi li rivada.
query.result:
**English:**
37 A devil is here behind who slaughters us 38 so cruelly, at the cut of the sword 39 sending each of this herd back,
40 when we have turned on the sorrowful road; 41 because the wounds are closed up 42 before another comes up in front of them.
**Old English:**
37 Deofol is her on bæc ðe us sliteð 38 swiðe grimlice, æt ordæs ecge, 39 eft sendað ðone ðe ðisne heap ræseð,
40 ðonne we ða wælræste gewendeð; 41 forðæm ðe ða wunda bið gebundene 42 ær ðon oder cumað him beforan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Ma tu chi se’ che ’n su lo scoglio muse, 44 forse per indugiar d’ire a la pena 45 ch’è giudicata in su le tue accuse?».
query.result:
**English:**
43 But you, who are you that muse upon the rock, 44 perhaps to delay going to the punishment 45 that is judged based on your accusations?”
**Old English:**
43 Ac ðu ðe eart ðe on ðam stan hlimme, 44 forðæm ðe ðu woldest ðine wíte ofercuman, 45 ðæt ðe bið gedemed æfter ðinum gewyrhtum?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «Né morte ’l giunse ancor, né colpa ’l mena», 47 rispuose ’l mio maestro, «a tormentarlo; 48 ma per dar lui esperïenza piena,
49 a me, che morto son, convien menarlo 50 per lo ’nferno qua giù di giro in giro; 51 e quest’ è ver così com’ io ti parlo».
query.result:
**English:**
46 "Nor has death yet overtaken him, nor does sin lead him," 47 replied my master, "to torment him; 48 but in order to give him full experience,
49 I, who am dead, must lead him 50 through Hell down here, from circle to circle; 51 and this is true, just as I am telling you."
**Old English:**
46 "Ne ðeah deð ne giet ðone monn to cwale," 47 andswarode min lareow, "to ðam tintregum; 48 ac for ðam ðe he sceal habban fulne andgit,
49 me, ðe ðeah deð is, gebyreð ðæt ic hine læde 50 ðurh helle geond ðas ymbrenu; 51 and ðis is soð, swa ic ðe secge."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Più fuor di cento che, quando l’udiro, 53 s’arrestaron nel fosso a riguardarmi 54 per maraviglia, oblïando il martiro.
query.result:
**English:**
52 More than a hundred who, when they heard me, 53 stopped in the ditch to look at me, 54 forgetting their torment in their amazement.
**Old English:**
52 Ma ðonne hundred ðe ða ðe ðæt gehyrdon, 53 ða gestodon on ðam dic ðe ðær wæron 54 ðurh wundor ðæs ðe ðær gesawon, 55 ðæt hi ðæs wite forgeahton.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «Or dì a fra Dolcin dunque che s’armi, 56 tu che forse vedra’ il sole in breve, 57 s’ello non vuol qui tosto seguitarmi,
58 sì di vivanda, che stretta di neve 59 non rechi la vittoria al Noarese, 60 ch’altrimenti acquistar non saria leve».
query.result:
**English:**
55 "Now tell Friar Dolcino to take up arms, 56 you who perhaps will soon see the sun, 57 if he does not want to follow me here soon,
58 with enough provisions, so that the harsh snow 59 does not bring victory to the Novarese, 60 which otherwise would not be easy to achieve."
**Old English:**
55 "Nu secge ðu ðam freond Dolcine ðæt he hine wæpnige, 56 ðu ðe miht ðone sunnan sona geseon, 57 gif he her hraðe ne wile me folgian,
58 mid ðære foðan ðe ðæs snæwes styrnys 59 ðam Novarese sige ne geuðe, 60 ðe elles ne mæg beon eaðe geboht."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Poi che l’un piè per girsene sospese, 62 Mäometto mi disse esta parola; 63 indi a partirsi in terra lo distese.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then, when one foot he had lifted to go, 62 Muhammad spoke to me this word; 63 then, parting, he stretched it out on the ground.
**Old English:**
61 Þa ða he ðone ænne fot on ða færelde sette, 62 ða cwæð Mahmet to me ðas word; 63 ða he on ða eorðan hine astrehte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Un altro, che forata avea la gola 65 e tronco ’l naso infin sotto le ciglia, 66 e non avea mai ch’una orecchia sola,
67 ristato a riguardar per maraviglia 68 con li altri, innanzi a li altri aprì la canna, 69 ch’era di fuor d’ogne parte vermiglia,
70 e disse: «O tu cui colpa non condanna 71 e cu’ io vidi su in terra latina, 72 se troppa simiglianza non m’inganna,
73 rimembriti di Pier da Medicina, 74 se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano 75 che da Vercelli a Marcabò dichina.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Another, who had his throat pierced through, 65 and his nose cut off up to the eyebrows, 66 and had only one ear left,
67 stopped to look in wonder 68 with the others, and opened his windpipe before the others, 69 which was red all over on the outside,
70 and said: "O you whom no fault condemns, 71 and whom I saw up there in Italy, 72 if too much resemblance does not deceive me,
73 remember Pier da Medicina, 74 if ever you return to see the sweet plain 75 that slopes down from Vercelli to Marcabò.
**Old English:**
64 An oðer, ðe ðurh ða ðrote wæs ðurhwunded, 65 and ða næse of ðam neb oftorfod, 66 and næfde buton an eare,
67 stod and wundrode mid ðam oðrum, 68 and ða ðrote ontynde beforan ðam oðrum, 69 ðe wæs utan ymb ða sidan read,
70 and cwæð: "Ðu ðe nænig gylt ne demð, 71 and ðe ic geseah ðær ufan on ðam eorðrice, 72 gif ðe to swiðe gelicnes ne beswicað,
73 geðenc ðe Pieres ðæs læces, 74 gif ðu æfre eft cymst ðæt ðu mote geseon 75 ðone swete feld ðe of Vercelie to Marcabò lið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 E fa saper a’ due miglior da Fano, 77 a messer Guido e anco ad Angiolello, 78 che, se l’antiveder qui non è vano,
79 gittati saran fuor di lor vasello 80 e mazzerati presso a la Cattolica 81 per tradimento d’un tiranno fello.
query.result:
**English:**
76 And let the two best from Fano know, 77 Messer Guido and also Angiolello, 78 that, if my foresight is not in vain here,
79 they will be thrown out of their ship 80 and killed near Cattolica 81 through the treachery of a cruel tyrant.
**Old English:**
76 AndhataðæmtwæmbetstanFana, 77 mæsseGwideandAngiolelle, 78 ðæt,gifðætföreseonnisnisna,
79 beoðaworpeneofheorascype, 80 and ofslagene æt ðære Cætelican, 81 ðurh swicdóm ænes felan tyrans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Tra l’isola di Cipri e di Maiolica 83 non vide mai sì gran fallo Nettuno, 84 non da pirate, non da gente argolica.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Between the island of Cyprus and Majorca 83 Neptune never saw such a great disaster, 84 not from pirates, not from the Argive people.
**Old English:**
82 Betwux ðære igðe ðe is Cipres and Maiolica 83 ne geseah næfre Neptunus swilcne gefeallan, 84 ne ðurh sæliðend ne ðurh Arge lifðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Quel traditor che vede pur con l’uno, 86 e tien la terra che tale qui meco 87 vorrebbe di vedere esser digiuno,
88 farà venirli a parlamento seco; 89 poi farà sì, ch’al vento di Focara 90 non sarà lor mestier voto né preco».
query.result:
**English:**
85 That traitor who sees with only one eye, 86 and holds the land that he, like me here, 87 would wish to be fasting from seeing,
88 will summon them to a meeting with him; 89 then he will arrange it so that in the wind of Focara 90 they will have no need for vows or prayers.
**Old English:**
85 Se ðæs forræderes ðe mid anum eage gesihð, 86 and ða eðel healdeð ðe he her mid me 87 wolde ðæt he ðæs gesihðes fæste,
88 ða ða gesamnigeð to spræce wið hine; 89 ðonne gedihð he ðæt ðæt him on ðam winde of Focara 90 ne bið ðearf bêne né gebede».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 E io a lui: «Dimostrami e dichiara, 92 se vuo’ ch’i’ porti sù di te novella, 93 chi è colui da la veduta amara».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I to him: "Show me and declare, 92 if you want me to carry news of you above, 93 who is he with the bitter sight?"
**Old English:**
91 And ic to him: "Ateoða and secge me, 92 gif ðu wylt ðæt ic ðe uppe bære, 93 hwa is se ðe ða bitre gesihðe hæfð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Allor puose la mano a la mascella 95 d’un suo compagno e la bocca li aperse, 96 gridando: «Questi è desso, e non favella.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Then he placed his hand on the jaw 95 of one of his companions and opened his mouth, 96 shouting: "This is he, and he does not speak.
**Old English:**
94 Þa he ongan his geferan gripe 95 ðæs muð and his muð openede, 96 clipiende: "Þes is se ðe ne spriced.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Questi, scacciato, il dubitar sommerse 98 in Cesare, affermando che ’l fornito 99 sempre con danno l’attender sofferse».
query.result:
**English:**
97 This one, being banished, drowned doubt 98 in Caesar, affirming that he who is prepared 99 always suffered harm by waiting.
**Old English:**
97 Þes, aworpen, ðone tweon adræncte 98 on Cesere, secgende ðæt se gefylceda 99 symle mid yrmðe ðone anbid abide.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Oh quanto mi pareva sbigottito 101 con la lingua tagliata ne la strozza 102 Curïo, ch’a dir fu così ardito!
103 E un ch’avea l’una e l’altra man mozza, 104 levando i moncherin per l’aura fosca, 105 sì che ’l sangue facea la faccia sozza,
106 gridò: «Ricordera’ti anche del Mosca, 107 che disse, lasso!, “Capo ha cosa fatta”, 108 che fu mal seme per la gente tosca».
query.result:
**English:**
100 Oh, how terrified I seemed 101 with my tongue cut off in my throat, 102 Curio, who was so bold in speaking!
103 And one who had both hands cut off, 104 raising his stumps in the murky air, 105 so that the blood made his face filthy,
106 cried out: "Remember Mosca too, 107 who said, alas!, 'A thing done has an end,' 108 which was an evil seed for the Tuscan people."
**Old English:**
100 Eala, hu micel me ðuhte ðæt ic wæs 101 on ðære tungan ðe wæs on ðære strupan ofslægen, 102 Curius, ðe wæs swiðe dyrstig on his spræce!
103 And sum ðe hæfde ða twa handa ofslegene, 104 ða earmas he ða up ahof on ðære dimman lyfte, 105 swa ðæt ðæt blod geworhte ðæt ansyn ful unfæger,
106 clypode ða and cwæð: "Gemune ðu ðe eac ðæs Moscan, 107 ðe cwæð, wæla wá, 'Þing gedón hæfð ende,' 108 ðæt wæs yfel sæd Toscanum leodum."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 E io li aggiunsi: «E morte di tua schiatta»; 110 per ch’elli, accumulando duol con duolo, 111 sen gio come persona trista e matta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And I added to him: "And death to your lineage"; 110 so that he, accumulating grief upon grief, 111 went away like a sad and mad person.
**Old English:**
109 And ic him ða to ðysum cwæð: "And ðinne cynnes deað"; 110 ðurh ðæt he, gedrefednesse on gedrefednesse geicðende, 111 ferde swa swa unrot man and gedwolena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Di sé facea a sé stesso lucerna, 125 ed eran due in uno e uno in due; 126 com’ esser può, quei sa che sì governa.
query.result:
**English:**
124 He made of himself a lamp unto himself, 125 and they were two in one and one in two; 126 how it can be, he knows who so governs it.
**Old English:**
124 He geworhte of him sylfum leoht to him sylfum, 125 and wæron twegen on anum and an on twam; 126 hu hit mæg wesan, ðæt wat se ðe swa gewealdeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Quando diritto al piè del ponte fue, 128 levò ’l braccio alto con tutta la testa 129 per appressarne le parole sue,
130 che fuoro: «Or vedi la pena molesta, 131 tu che, spirando, vai veggendo i morti: 132 vedi s’alcuna è grande come questa.
query.result:
**English:**
127 When he was right at the foot of the bridge, 128 he raised his arm high with all his head 129 to bring his words closer,
130 which were: "Now see the grievous punishment, 131 you who, breathing, go seeing the dead: 132 see if any is as great as this.
**Old English:**
127 Þa he rihte æt ðæs brycge fót wæs, 128 he áhóf his earm héah mid ealre his heafde 129 forðæm ðe he wolde his word néah
130 ða wæron: "Nú ðu gesyh ða sárlican wíte, 131 ðu ðe, blowende, gæst geseonde ða deadan: 132 geseoh ðu gif ænig síe máre ðonne ðis.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 E perché tu di me novella porti, 134 sappi ch’i’ son Bertram dal Bornio, quelli 135 che diedi al re giovane i ma’ conforti.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And so that you may carry news of me, 134 know that I am Bertran de Born, he 135 who gave evil advice to the young king.
**Old English:**
133 And forðæm ðe ðu ðinra tiðenda mæge 134 witan ðæt ic eom Bertran de Born, se ðe 135 ðæm geongan cyninge yfele rædas sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Io feci il padre e ’l figlio in sé ribelli; 137 Achitofèl non fé più d’Absalone 138 e di Davìd coi malvagi punzelli.
query.result:
**English:**
136 I made the father and the son rebellious against each other; 137 Ahithophel did no more to Absalom 138 and David with the evil counselors.
**Old English:**
136 Ic geworhte ðone fæder and ðone sunu on him sylfum rebellas; 137 Ahitofel ne dyde na mare to Absalone 138 and to Dauide mid ðam yflum rædesmannum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Perch’ io parti’ così giunte persone, 140 partito porto il mio cerebro, lasso!, 141 dal suo principio ch’è in questo troncone.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Because I split apart such closely united people, 140 I carry my brain, alas!, divided 141 from its origin, which is in this trunk.
**Old English:**
139 Forðæm ic todælde ða swiðe gesomnodan, 140 todæled ic bære min geðoht, la!, 141 fram his fruman ðe is on ðissum stocce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Così s’osserva in me lo contrapasso».
query.result:
**English:**
142 Thus is the retribution observed in me.
**Old English:**
142 Swa is on me ðæt wipermearc gesewen.
